column1: As a wallet user I want my account to lock if there is an attempt to log in 3 times with the incorrect pin
column28:
*Acceptance Criteria*

* If an attempt to login fails due to an incorrect pin the account should not allow the user to  try again (E.g. show the user a message like: ‚ÄúYou have failed to enter the correct pin 3 times. Please reset your pin in order to access your account.‚Äú
* The account can be retrieved by resetting the pin via the security questions.
column99:
10/Jul/23 1:29 PM;621880712d1a9d0069968d6b;Implementation Plan:
web-server:
* add {{account_attempts: u32}} to {{WalletStorable}}
* when {{open_wallet}} is called, increase {{account_attempts}}  by 1 if {{open_wallet}} fails for incorrect pin
* when {{open_wallet}} succeeds, reset {{account_attempts}} to 0
* when {{create_wallet}} is called for new wallet initialize {{account_attempts}} to 0
* for existing accounts, if {{account_attempts}} is none, or not there, add it to {{WalletStorable}} when {{open_wallet}} is called
* when {{open_wallet}} is called and {{account_attempts}} is equal to 3 or greater (should not be possible), return Account Lock Error with message: ‚ÄúYou have failed to enter the correct pin 3 times. Please reset your pin in order to access your account.‚Äú even if the pin is correct
* when {{pin_reset}} is called and OTP is successful, set new pin and reset {{account_attempts}} to 0.

web-client:
* When user tries to log in and receives Account Lock Error, display appropriate message

Notes:
* This doesn‚Äôt prevent strangers from just trying random passwords 3 times and locking your account
- can add a Captcha to make sure logins are humans and for added security

Create an ecall that takes a sealed seed and an unsigned transaction while returning a signed version of the latter using an unsealed version of the former.

Overview
Currently, the wallet seals all wallet data using a single key that is derived from both the MRENCLAVE and MRSIGNER  values.  The former, called the enclave measurement, is a cryptographic hash derived from a combination of the enclave code and the initial data loaded into the enclave.  The latter value is a hash, called the author identity, of the public key corresponding to the private key used to sign the enclave executable.

The enclave supports two modes of sealing:
Sealing to the current enclave,
Sealing to the enclave author.
A summary of these two modes follows but further information may be found in the SGX Developer Guide in the section on sealing policies found on pp. 28.

Data sealed the current enclave ensures that only (instances of) the current enclave may access it.  This guarantees that a different enclave on the same hardware are unable to access this data.  This has the side-effect that new iterations of the implementation of an enclave will be unable to access data sealed to a prior version, since these enclaves will be assigned different measurements and thus derive distinct key pairs.

The second mode of sealing makes it possible for new versions of an enclave to access data that was sealed for a prior version of the enclave.  The consequence, however, is that it makes the author of the enclave a trusted party and hence necessary precautions should be put in place to protect the private key used to sign the enclave executable.  

That said, the low entropy of the user PINs stored within the enclave Protected FS storage means that it is already necessary for a user to trust parties involved in the day-to-day operations of the Nautilus Wallet as a whole.  The SGX by itself does not provide the mechanisms necessary to allow trustless operation while using low entropy secrets for authentication purposes.  Furthermore, the Protected FS API provided by the SGX SDK limits write access to only a single application thread on any given hardware installation at a time.

Overview
The Azure Web PubSub service may be used in a solution by employing the Azure Python SDK.  This service provides functionality to send messages/notifications to targeted users, even across multiple devices.  In order to connect to the service and receive such messages, the user is authenticated via a JWT issued by our server.  We are required to implement an authentication mechanism through which these JWTs may be issued to a user upon verifying their credentials.
Server
Functionality for checking the state of transactions broadcast to the blockchain needs to be added.  Additionally, an authorization service is required in order to authenticate users before issuing a JWT they may use to access the PubSub service.

Client
Connections to the PubSub service are established over the WebSocket protocol and communication may take place in either JSON or Protobuf format, the former being preferable (and simpler) on the client side.  Before such a connection may be established, a client needs to request a JWT from our server by presenting the necessary credentials.  This JWT may then be used to access notifications from the PubSub service until its expiry date, at which point a new JWT will have to be requested.

Breakdown
DevOps
Create a new Azure PubSub instance.
Add cryptographic keys to the appropriate container environments:
The Azure PubSub access keys for JWT signing
The pepper used in the password hashing process
Server
Add functionality for housing a salted hash of the user's PIN in the database.  This hash should be computed using the Argon2id algorithm and may be implemented using the corresponding crate from the RustCrypto project:
Implement a python class called Argon2 in Rust, using pyo3:
Minimal: the class should be able to compute hashes of passwords by using the user's wallet id as a salt as well as a pepper passed to it.  The class should also have a method used to verify password attempts
Ideal: the hash stored in the database is computed using an enclave-derived pepper.  This would require that the initial computation of the hash be performed within the enclave. 
New hashed passwords should be stored as a field in the database for each user
A new FastAPI endpoint will be necessary for OAuth2 calls that grant new JWTs for accessing the aforementioned Azure PubSub service.
Add an environment secret and implement an Oauth2 class that receives user credentials and verifies them using the Argon2 class above and the hash from the database, returning a signed JWT using the python-jose library in a vein similar to the FastAPI example.  The JWT is signed using the Azure PubSub access keys.
Create a new FastAPI endpoint for issuing JWTs to authenticated users.
Add a notification service to the application server that provides functionality for sending notifications to targeted users:
Create a NotifyUser class that has a method that sends a specified user a provided message via the Azure PubSub service.  This is implemented by calling the send_to_user method provided by the Azure SDK.
Add an XRPL service to the application server:
Minimal:
Add an endpoint which receives transaction IDs and may be used by authenticated clients to notify our system of newly sent transactions.
Implement a new LookupTxn class that has a lookup  method for looking up arbitrary transactions, via their id, to confirm that they have been committed to the blockchain, returning a ConfirmedTxn class.
The ConfirmedTxn class should implement a notify_users method which utilizes the NotifyUser class above to notify the sender and recipient of the transaction. Note that recipients can only be notified if they are registered in our database.
Ideal:  Move the broadcasting of transactions from the client to the server.  This removes the reliance on clients to report their transactions back to us, reducing the possibility of failure, as it would be known to the server when new transactions are sent to the blockchain.  This also serves to reduce the complexity of our architecture and will, in fact, become mandatory if the ledger nodes become permissioned instances as has been suggested by Ripple.

Store each bookmark as a separate document (with sealed bookmark and nickname)
